awd_abstract_narration: This is a proposal to develop an improved aequorin method of                    measuring cytoplasmic calcium levels.  Aequorin is a                            chemiluminescent protein extracted rom a jellyfish.  Its                        luminescence increases rapidly with calcium concentration over the              whole range found within living cells and it can be injected                    without disturbing their function or development.  The pattern and              level of luminescence which is emitted by an aequorin-loaded cell               serves to reveal the changing patterns and levels of free calcium               within this cell for days after injection.                                                                                                                      The aequorin method has several advantages over fluorescent dye                 techniques currently used for measuring cytoplasmic calcium levels.             However, it requires improving for it to reach its full potential.              Dr. Jaffe will develop an efficient imaging system and a way for                mass loading of aequorin into cells, using fertilized sea urchin                eggs, Dictyostelium cells, and other cells.                                                                                                                     If successful, the improved aequorin method will increase our                   ability to accurately measure the cytoplasmic calcium levels and                will contribute to better understanding of many cell and                        developmental processes that involve calcium.
